#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=CHAPTER II --
#Text=THE BONDAGE
#Text=The days were thronged with experience for White Fang .
#Text=During the time that Kiche was tied by the stick , he ran about over all the camp , inquiring , investigating , learning .
#Text=He quickly came to know much of the ways of the man-animals , but familiarity did not breed contempt .
#Text=The more he came to know them , the more they vindicated their superiority , the more they displayed their mysterious powers , the greater loomed their god-likeness .

#Text=To man has been given the grief , often , of seeing his gods overthrown and his altars crumbling ; but to the wolf and the wild dog that have come in to crouch at man 's feet , this grief has never come .

#Text=Unlike man , whose gods are of the unseen and the overguessed , vapours and mists of fancy eluding the garmenture of reality , wandering wraiths of desired goodness and power , intangible out-croppings of self into the realm of spirit -- unlike man , the wolf and the wild dog that have come in to the fire find their gods in the living flesh , solid to the touch , occupying earth-space and requiring time for the accomplishment of their ends and their existence .
#Text=No effort of faith is necessary to believe in such a god ; no effort of will can possibly induce disbelief in such a god .
#Text=There is no getting away from it .

#Text=There it stands , on its two hind-legs , club in hand , immensely potential , passionate and wrathful and loving , god and mystery and power all wrapped up and around by flesh that bleeds when it is torn and that is good to eat like any flesh .
#Text=And so it was with White Fang .
#Text=The man-animals were gods unmistakable and unescapable .
#Text=As his mother , Kiche , had rendered her allegiance to them at the first cry of her name , so he was beginning to render his allegiance .
#Text=He gave them the trail as a privilege indubitably theirs .
#Text=When they walked , he got out of their way .
#Text=When they called , he came .
#Text=When they threatened , he cowered down .
#Text=When they commanded him to go , he went away hurriedly .
#Text=For behind any wish of theirs was power to enforce that wish , power that hurt , power that expressed itself in clouts and clubs , in flying stones and stinging lashes of whips .
#Text=He belonged to them as all dogs belonged to them .
#Text=His actions were theirs to command .
#Text=His body was theirs to maul , to stamp upon , to tolerate .
#Text=Such was the lesson that was quickly borne in upon him .

#Text=It came hard , going as it did , counter to much that was strong and dominant in his own nature ; and , while he disliked it in the learning of it , unknown to himself he was learning to like it .
#Text=It was a placing of his destiny in another 's hands , a shifting of the responsibilities of existence .
#Text=This in itself was compensation , for it is always easier to lean upon another than to stand alone .
#Text=But it did not all happen in a day , this giving over of himself , body and soul , to the man-animals .
#Text=He could not immediately forego his wild heritage and his memories of the Wild .
#Text=There were days when he crept to the edge of the forest and stood and listened to something calling him far and away .
#Text=And always he returned , restless and uncomfortable , to whimper softly and wistfully at Kiche 's side and to lick her face with eager , questioning tongue .
#Text=White Fang learned rapidly the ways of the camp .
#Text=He knew the injustice and greediness of the older dogs when meat or fish was thrown out to be eaten .
#Text=He came to know that men were more just , children more cruel , and women more kindly and more likely to toss him a bit of meat or bone .

#Text=And after two or three painful adventures with the mothers of part-grown puppies , he came into the knowledge that it was always good policy to let such mothers alone , to keep away from them as far as possible , and to avoid them when he saw them coming .
#Text=But the bane of his life was Lip-lip .
#Text=Larger , older , and stronger , Lip- lip had selected White Fang for his special object of persecution .
#Text=While Fang fought willingly enough , but he was outclassed .
#Text=His enemy was too big .

#Text=Lip-lip became a nightmare to him . Whenever he ventured away from his mother , the bully was sure to appear , trailing at his heels , snarling at him , picking upon him , and watchful of an opportunity , when no man- animal was near , to spring upon him and force a fight .
#Text=As Lip-lip invariably won , he enjoyed it hugely .
#Text=It became his chief delight in life , as it became White Fang 's chief torment .
#Text=But the effect upon White Fang was not to cow him . Though he suffered most of the damage and was always defeated , his spirit remained unsubdued .
#Text=Yet a bad effect was produced .
#Text=He became malignant and morose .
#Text=His temper had been savage by birth , but it became more savage under this unending persecution .
#Text=The genial , playful , puppyish side of him found little expression .
#Text=He never played and gambolled about with the other puppies of the camp .
#Text=Lip-lip would not permit it .
#Text=The moment White Fang appeared near them , Lip-lip was upon him , bullying and hectoring him , or fighting with him until he had driven him away .
